cards.back: i = C·dv/dt. Current flows only when voltage changes. At DC: i = 0, capacitor is an open circuit.
v = L·di/dt. Voltage appears only when current changes. At DC: v = 0, inductor is a short circuit.
Their state (v_C or i_L) depends on the integral of past current/voltage — the entire history from −∞ to t — unlike resistors which are memoryless (v = Ri depends only on current NOW).

cards.front: Energy stored in a capacitor and inductor?
cards.back: E_C = ½Cv² (electrostatic). E_L = ½Li² (magnetic). Both always ≥ 0, stored not dissipated (lossless elements).

cards.front: What is the duality principle for C and L?
cards.back: Swap v↔i, C↔L, R↔G, series↔parallel. Every capacitor theorem has a dual inductor theorem. E.g., i=C·dv/dt ↔ v=L·di/dt.

cards.front: What is the small-signal capacitance C(v)?
cards.back: C(v) = dq̂(v)/dv — the slope of the q-v characteristic at operating point v. Constant for linear capacitors; varies with v for nonlinear (e.g., varactors).
v(t) = v(t₀) + (1/C)∫_{t₀}^{t} i(τ)dτ. The voltage depends on the accumulated charge from t₀ to t plus the initial condition.

cards.front: What are the four basic circuit elements?
cards.back: Resistor (v↔i), Capacitor (q↔v), Inductor (Φ↔i), Memristor (Φ↔q). Together they link all four pairings of v, i, q, Φ.

cards.front: What happens if you connect a DC source directly to an ideal capacitor?
cards.back: dv/dt → ∞ implies i → ∞ (impulse). Physically impossible without resistance. This motivates the delta function δ(t) concept.

cards.front: Phase relationship between v and i in a capacitor (AC)?
cards.back: Current LEADS voltage by 90°. i = C·dv/dt means when v = sin(ωt), i = ωC·cos(ωt). Peak current occurs at zero voltage crossing (maximum dv/dt).
